title: 10 best dried flowers that are environmentally friendly and long lasting
text:
Fresh flowers around the home are one of life’s greatest luxuries but replacing them weekly is costly and time-consuming. It’s little wonder, then, that modern-day flora fans are searching for alternatives that last and save money in the long term while looking just as pretty.



Faux flowers remain popular (we rounded up some of the best earlier this year) but there’s no getting past the fact that even the most convincing aren’t real. Here’s where dried flowers come into play.



Sold in bunches, wreaths and as individual stems, this trend seems to have stemmed from the idea of creating a wedding bouquet you can keep sentimentally for longer. But there’s no need to be getting married to jump on the bandwagon – many people are buying dried flowers to display around the home.

And what’s even better is that these blooms are environmentally friendly too, thanks to their long shelf life, low carbon footprint and biodegradability.

Trouva, the online home of the best independent boutiques, has seen a staggering 103 per cent rise in dried flowers sales year on year, with customers “going wild” for them.

But while dried flowers have a unique rustic beauty, they are brittle and can be extremely delicate. Even the most considered packaging and postal service may damage them at least slightly. Preserved flowers, such as those from The Magic Flower Company, below, will fare better in transit. Their natural sap has been replaced with a special, plant-based liquid that keeps them looking fresh, soft and colourful for a year or more.



When it comes to arranging, floral stylist and author Carolyn Dunster follows the Japanese philosophy of wabi-sabi, which teaches us to appreciate the imperfect beauty of nature. “Stay minimal and keep it monotype,” she says. “Choose earthenware, clay, woven and handmade containers over anything too new and shiny, wire up a simple hoop to hang above a bed or secure dried bunches onto doorknobs.”

You can trust our independent reviews. We may earn commission from some of the retailers, but we never allow this to influence selections, which are formed from real-world testing and expert advice. This revenue helps to fund journalism across The Independent.

Dot and the Dandelion Ophelia in a can: £25, Dot and the Dandelion

This pretty dried posy arrived in excellent condition through the post, with only a few petals dropping off the daintiest of flowers. For the very fair price of £25, you get a decently sized bunch of strawflowers, larkspur and broom that looks like it’s been picked from the hedgerows and an old tin can laminated with a replica vintage label for that retro touch. Both parts come wrapped in pale peach tissue paper with the flowers already arranged and tied with a cream hessian ribbon for minimum faff. We think they’d make wonderfully quirky centrepieces for a summer wedding, as well as brightening up an empty shelf where houseplants keep wilting on you.

Buy now

Little Deer dried natural poppy seed head bunch: £10.50, Trouva​

It’s hard not to be instantly struck by the sculptural beauty of these dried poppy seed heads from Brighton homeware boutique Little Deer. Each stem is 55cm long and you get 10 per bunch, with beautiful natural dissimilitude in the size, shape and texture of each. Either make a strong, minimalist statement by grouping them all together or pair them with other flower species as part of a bigger bouquet. They’re delivered in a sturdy box, wrapped in brown kraft paper and bubble wrap, so don’t worry about them being ruined en route. Little Deer also stocks a stunning – and currently hugely popular – range of dried pampas grass, as well as some exotic dried palm leaves.

Buy now

Shida preserved flowers Manhattan: £39, Shida Preserved Florist

The hot pink hydrangea steals the spotlight in this chic preserved bouquet. Nestled among eucalyptus and solidago, you’d never guess it wasn’t freshly picked, yet it should last a good year. This modern brand has a knack for peppering leafy foliage with a few statement flowers that would naturally grow nearby and arranging them in a wild, asymmetric style. Natural glycerine and dyes maintain the cell structure of the plants, meaning they stay soft and colourful for many months. You can also buy individual stems from this florist and sign up or gift subscriptions. The flowers are carefully hand-packed, wrapped in paper and a recyclable box, some of which fit through the letterbox.

Buy now

The Dried Flower Shop vintage garden rose bouquet: £95, The Dried Flower Shop

Roses may be soft, fleshy flowers but they dry surprisingly beautifully and these burgundy and pink roses are a stunning example. Dried flowers often struggle to keep their colour well but rich tones are abound here from golden amaranthus to blue lavender. The bouquet, from British eco florist The Dried Flower Shop, arrives bound in hessian and finished fabulously with a thick gold ribbon. This sustainably minded brand packs all its flowers as tightly as possible into recycled boxes to minimise movement and keep even the most fragile petals safe. This is one of their pricier creations – again aimed at brides – but if you’re after something more affordable, look to these distressed metal churns filled with your choice of pink or yellow flowers.

Buy now

The Mighty Quinns Flower Emporium dried cotton stalks: £18.40, The Mighty Quinns Flower Emporium

It’s impossible to resist stroking these soft and fluffy dried cotton stalks, which pair beautifully with other dried flowers and seedheads as well as holding their own in a Scandi-inspired home. Bristol-based boutique The Mighty Quinns Flower Emporium has a love affair with nature and recommends showing these cotton beauties to children who might be interested to see what it looks like before it’s made into their clothes. You get five stems per order – good value for less than £20 – and they’re one of the safer bets for delivery as they aren’t as fragile as dried petals.

Buy now

Grace & Thorn some things do last forever bridal bouquet: From £100, Grace & Thorn

Make a confident, classy statement with this wild-looking arrangement of dried flowers in rich burgundy, soft pink and elegant ivory. Designed for brides to keep long after their big day is over, hip east-London florist Grace & Thorn hunts out the best seasonal flowers, from lavender and delphinium to cornflowers and hydrangea. They’re all tied together in a non-contrived style with a hand-dyed silk ribbon. If you do want this bouquet for your wedding, a big pro is that they can be delivered in advance without dying on you, meaning one less thing to stress over! Note that the small size costs £100 but the larger size shown here is £150.

Buy now

The Magic Flower Company woodland hand-tied bunch: £44.94, The Magic Flower Company

This small Suffolk-based florist “magically” makes its flowers live for a year by carefully replacing their natural sap with a non-toxic, plant-based glycerine solution and enhancing the colour of the petals with organic dyes. Our pick of the perfectly preserved bunch is this timeless selection of foliage in shades of green and grey. Keep the sprays together for classy, pared-back vibes (they look dramatic against a pale wall) or mix them with flowers for added texture. Each arrangement is lovingly put together by experts, with individual stems and custom bouquets also available if you fancy getting creative. Keep them looking their best by placing them out of direct sunlight and humidity. They won’t be happy in water but if you pop them into an opaque vase, nobody will ever know...

Buy now

Shropshire Petals burgundy wheat wreath: £42, Not on the High Street

Ramp up your kerb appeal by hanging one of these whimsical wreaths from confetti-growing experts Shropshire Petals on your front door. Each one is handmade from wheat that is grown, harvested and air dried on the brand’s Shopshire farm. Dried burgundy rose heads, nigella pod, marjoram, white larkspur and fluffy lambs tail are then added for colour and texture. You can expect it to look its best for three to four months before the colours start to fade, but it’ll look charmingly characterful further down the line and you could always weave in some more dried flowers of your choice. There’s a choice of 12 satin ribbon colours, from classic neutrals to purple silver and gold. Do note that this unique decoration will not fare well in rain, so only hang it outside if covered by a porch!

Buy now

The Artisan Dried Flower Company Festival Meadow dried flower wedding bouquet: from £29, Not on the High Street

Boho brides and fans of country living will fall for the carefree vibe of this dried bouquet available in three sizes: bride (£53), bridesmaid (£39), and flower girl (£29). The flowers are cut and dried naturally from the company’s own flower farm in Staffordshire. Expect to find larkspur, lavender, daisies, yarrow, oats and gypsophila in your bunch, which will be handmade to order by an RHS award-winning stylist. If you want matching wedding accessories, there’s a full Festival Meadow collection to browse, including an adorable dog collar!

Buy now

Pompon Bazar purple bouquet: £42.49, Trouva

Bring a touch of that Parisian je ne sais quoi into your home with this loud and proud bouquet of dried flowers and grasses from chic boutique Pompon Bazar, found in the French capital. We love the bold colour combination of deep magenta, hot coral and natural wheat, which will really zing against a neutral interior palette. Delivery will be a few pounds more expensive than usual as your order will be coming from abroad, but as dried flowers go these are among the more robust during travel.

Buy now

The verdict: Dried flowers

We were impressed by the value for money offered by Dot and the Dandelion and loved how its joyful Ophelia bouquet came in a vintage tin can for displaying – it’d make a great gift for someone without the energy for flower arranging. The hydrangea-led bunch of preserved flowers from Shida Preserved Flowers is an excellent choice if you prefer your flowers to look fresh but don’t want the maintenance faff.

IndyBest product reviews are unbiased, independent advice you can trust. On some occasions, we earn revenue if you click the links and buy the products, but we never allow this to bias our coverage. The reviews are compiled through a mix of expert opinion and real-world testing.
description: Modernise your flower arrangements with these dried flowers from Not on the High Street, Trouva and Grace & Thorn
